universum.studios.android.fragment.manage

Class FragmentController

  • java.lang.Object
    • universum.studios.android.fragment.manage.FragmentController

  • public class FragmentController
extends Object
    FragmentController class is designed primarily to simplify Fragments management within an Android application.

    Whether it is desired to replace|add|remove|show|hide|attach|detach a specific Fragment, this may be requested via FragmentRequest. A new request may be created via newRequest(Fragment). Each fragment request is associated with the controller trough which it has been created and that controller is responsible for execution of fragment request when FragmentRequest.execute() is called.

    Factory

    The best advantage of the FragmentController and globally of this library may be accomplished by using of FragmentFactory attached to the desired fragment controller. Basically in an Android application you will use directly instances of the FragmentController to replace|add|hide... fragments and for each of that application screens (Activities) a single FragmentFactory may be defined which will provide fragment instances for that activity screen. For example, one fragment factory for main activity with navigation drawer where that factory will provide fragments for each of the items within the navigation menu. Than another fragment factory for profile activity and that factory will provide all fragments used within that activity, like fragment for displaying of user's info an another one for editing that info.

    The desired factory for FragmentController may be specified via setFactory(FragmentFactory). Fragment requests for fragments provided by the attached factory may be than created via newRequest(int). Note, that it is required that factory is attached to the controller before call to this method, otherwise an exception will be thrown.

    Fragments that are provided by factory attached to the fragment controller may be found via findFragmentByFactoryId(int) (when already displayed) by theirs corresponding id defined in the related factory.

    Callbacks

    If you want to listen for fragment request executions, a desired FragmentController.OnRequestListener may be attached to the FragmentController via registerOnRequestListener(OnRequestListener).

    If you want to listen for changes in the fragments back stack whenever a new fragment is added to the stack or an old one removed from the stack, a desired FragmentController.OnBackStackChangeListener may be attached to the FragmentController via registerOnBackStackChangeListener(OnBackStackChangeListener).

    Author:
    Martin Albedinsky
    See Also:
    FragmentFactory, FragmentRequest

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void clearBackStack()
      Clears fragments back stack by calling FragmentManager.popBackStack() in loop for current back stack size obtained via FragmentManager.getBackStackEntryCount().
      boolean clearBackStackImmediate()
      Like clearBackStack() but this will call FragmentManager.popBackStackImmediate() instead of FragmentManager.popBackStack().
      FragmentTransaction createTransaction(FragmentRequest request)
      Begins and configures a new FragmentTransaction for the given fragment request.
      void destroy()
      Destroys this fragment controller instance, mainly un-registering its internal back-stack listener from the attached FragmentManager.
      Fragment findCurrentFragment()
      Finds a fragment that is currently visible in the layout container with id specified via setViewContainerId(int).
      Fragment findFragmentByFactoryId(int factoryFragmentId)
      Delegates to FragmentManager.findFragmentByTag(String) with the TAG obtained via FragmentFactory.createFragmentTag(int) from the current factory.
      FragmentFactory getFactory()
      Returns the current fragment factory attached to this controller.

      Returns the fragment manager specified for this controller during its initialization.

      Returns the top entry from the fragments back stack.

      Returns id of the view container for fragment views.

    • Constructor Detail

      • FragmentController

        public FragmentController(@NonNull
                          Activity parentActivity)
        Creates a new instance of FragmentController for the given parentActivity.

        Passed activity will be used to obtain an instance of FragmentManager for the new controller.

        This constructor attaches the given activity to the new controller as one of interfaces listed below if the activity implements listed interfaces respectively:

        • FragmentRequestInterceptor -> setRequestInterceptor(FragmentRequestInterceptor)
        • FragmentController.OnRequestListener -> registerOnRequestListener(OnRequestListener)
        • FragmentController.OnBackStackChangeListener -> registerOnBackStackChangeListener(OnBackStackChangeListener)
        Parameters:
        parentActivity - The activity that wants to use the new fragment controller.
        See Also:
        FragmentController(Fragment)

      • FragmentController

        public FragmentController(@NonNull
                          Fragment parentFragment)
        Creates a new instance of FragmentController for the given parentFragment.

        Passed fragment will be used to obtain an instance of FragmentManager for the new controller.

        This constructor attaches the given fragment to the new controller as one of interfaces listed below if the fragment implements listed interfaces respectively:

        • FragmentRequestInterceptor -> setRequestInterceptor(FragmentRequestInterceptor)
        • FragmentController.OnRequestListener -> registerOnRequestListener(OnRequestListener)
        • FragmentController.OnBackStackChangeListener -> registerOnBackStackChangeListener(OnBackStackChangeListener)

        Do not forget to destroy the new controller via destroy() when the fragment is also destroyed.

        Parameters:
        parentFragment - The fragment that wants to use the new fragment controller.
        See Also:
        FragmentController(Activity)

      • FragmentController

        public FragmentController(@NonNull
                          FragmentManager fragmentManager)
        Creates a new instance of FragmentController with the given fragmentManager.
        Parameters:
        fragmentManager - Fragment manager that will be used to perform fragments related operations.
        See Also:
        FragmentController(Activity), FragmentController(Fragment)

      • getFragmentManager

public final FragmentManager getFragmentManager()
        Returns the fragment manager specified for this controller during its initialization.
        Returns:

      • setViewContainerId

        public final void setViewContainerId(@IdRes
                                     int containerId)
        Sets an id of a view container where to place view hierarchies of the desired fragments.

        Note, that this container id is used to specify initial/default container id for all FragmentRequests created via newRequest(Fragment)

        Parameters:
        containerId - The desired view container id.
        See Also:
        getViewContainerId()

      • getViewContainerId

        @IdRes
public final int getViewContainerId()
        Returns id of the view container for fragment views.
        Returns:
        View container id or NO_CONTAINER_ID if no id has been specified yet.
        See Also:
        setViewContainerId(int)

      • setFactory

        public void setFactory(@Nullable
                       FragmentFactory factory)
        Sets a fragment factory that should provide fragment instances for FragmentRequests created via newRequest(int).
        Parameters:
        factory - The desired factory. May null to clear the current one.
        See Also:

      • hasFactory

        public boolean hasFactory()
        Checks whether this controller has fragment factory attached or not.
        Returns:
        True if factory is attached, false otherwise.

        @Nullable
public FragmentFactory getFactory()

        Returns:
        This controller's factory or null if there is no factory attached yet.
        See Also:

      • setRequestInterceptor

        public void setRequestInterceptor(@Nullable
                                  FragmentRequestInterceptor interceptor)
        Sets an interceptor that may be used to intercept an execution of a FragmentRequest created via newRequest(Fragment) when execution of that request has been requested via FragmentRequest.execute().
        Parameters:
        interceptor - The desired interceptor. May be null to clear the current one.

      • registerOnRequestListener

        public void registerOnRequestListener(@NonNull
                                      FragmentController.OnRequestListener listener)
        Registers a callback to be invoked when a FragmentRequest is executed via this controller.

        Fragment request created via newRequest(Fragment) is executed whenever its FragmentRequest.execute() is called and the associated controller does not have FragmentRequestInterceptor attached or the attached interceptor did not intercept execution of that particular request.

        Parameters:
        listener - The desired listener callback to be registered.
        See Also:
        unregisterOnRequestListener(OnRequestListener)

      • unregisterOnRequestListener

        public void unregisterOnRequestListener(@NonNull
                                        FragmentController.OnRequestListener listener)
        Un-registers the given callback from the registered request listeners.
        Parameters:
        listener - The desired listener callback to be un-registered.
        See Also:
        registerOnRequestListener(OnRequestListener)

      • registerOnBackStackChangeListener

        public void registerOnBackStackChangeListener(@NonNull
                                              FragmentController.OnBackStackChangeListener listener)
        Registers a callback to be invoked when some change occurs in the fragments back stack.
        Parameters:
        listener - The desired listener callback to be registered.
        See Also:
        unregisterOnBackStackChangeListener(OnBackStackChangeListener), FragmentManager.addOnBackStackChangedListener(FragmentManager.OnBackStackChangedListener)

      • unregisterOnBackStackChangeListener

                                                FragmentController.OnBackStackChangeListener listener)

        Parameters:

        See Also:
        registerOnBackStackChangeListener(OnBackStackChangeListener)

      • newRequest

        @NonNull
public final FragmentRequest newRequest(int fragmentId)
        Creates a new instance of FragmentRequest for the given fragmentId. The new request will have the given fragment id attached along with this controller which will be responsible for execution of the new request when its FragmentRequest.execute() is called.

        Note, that execution of the created request assumes that there is factory attached and that factory provides fragment that is associated with the specified fragmentId otherwise an exception will be thrown.

        Parameters:
        fragmentId - Id of the desired factory fragment for which to crate the new request.
        Returns:
        New fragment request with the specified fragmentId id attached. Also specified id.

      • newRequest

        @NonNull
public final FragmentRequest newRequest(@NonNull
                                                  Fragment fragment)
        Creates a new FragmentRequest for the given fragment. The new request will have the given fragment attached along with this controller which will be responsible for execution of the new request when its FragmentRequest.execute() is called.

        The returned request will have default FRAGMENT_TAG attached via FragmentRequest.tag(String) and also view container id via FragmentRequest.viewContainerId(int) specified for this controller via setViewContainerId(int).

        Parameters:
        fragment - The fragment for which to create the new request.
        Returns:
        New fragment request with default FRAGMENT_TAG and container id specified for this controller via setViewContainerId(int).
        See Also:
        FragmentRequest.tag(String), FragmentRequest.viewContainerId(int)

      • onExecuteRequest

        @NonNull
protected Fragment onExecuteRequest(@NonNull
                                              FragmentRequest request)
        Called to perform execution of the given fragment request.

        This implementation creates a new FragmentTransaction via createTransaction(FragmentRequest) for the request and commits it via appropriate commit method and returns the associated fragment.

        Parameters:
        request - The fragment request of which execution has been requested via call to FragmentRequest.execute()
        Returns:
        The fragment associated with the request.

      • createTransaction

        @NonNull
public FragmentTransaction createTransaction(@NonNull
                                                       FragmentRequest request)
        Begins and configures a new FragmentTransaction for the given fragment request.

        The created transaction will be configured via methods listed below depending on configuration parameters supplied via the specified request:

        • FragmentTransaction.replace(int, Fragment, String)
        • FragmentTransaction.add(int, Fragment, String)
        • FragmentTransaction.remove(Fragment)
        • FragmentTransaction.show(Fragment)
        • FragmentTransaction.hide(Fragment)
        • FragmentTransaction.attach(Fragment)
        • FragmentTransaction.detach(Fragment)
        • FragmentTransaction.setCustomAnimations(int, int, int, int)
        • FragmentTransaction.setTransitionStyle(int)
        • FragmentTransaction.addSharedElement(View, String)
        • FragmentTransaction.addToBackStack(String)
        Also transitions related configuration will be performed for the fragment that is attached to the request via methods listed below:
        • Fragment.setEnterTransition(Transition)
        • Fragment.setExitTransition(Transition)
        • Fragment.setReenterTransition(Transition)
        • Fragment.setReturnTransition(Transition)
        • Fragment.setSharedElementEnterTransition(Transition)
        • Fragment.setSharedElementReturnTransition(Transition)
        • Fragment.setAllowEnterTransitionOverlap(boolean)
        • Fragment.setAllowReturnTransitionOverlap(boolean)

        Do not forget to commit the transaction.

        Parameters:
        request - The request specifying configuration parameters for the transaction to be created.
        Returns:
        The desired fragment transaction that may be immediately committed via one of FragmentTransaction.commit...() methods.
        Throws:
        IllegalArgumentException - If the request has specified transaction type of FragmentRequest.REPLACE or FragmentRequest.ADD but it has no container id specified via FragmentRequest.viewContainerId(int)

      • findCurrentFragment

        @Nullable
public Fragment findCurrentFragment()
        Finds a fragment that is currently visible in the layout container with id specified via setViewContainerId(int).
        Returns:
        Currently visible fragment or null if there is no fragment displayed in the fragment layout container.
        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - If there is no fragment container id specified.
        See Also:
        FragmentManager.findFragmentById(int)

      • findFragmentByFactoryId

        @Nullable
public Fragment findFragmentByFactoryId(int factoryFragmentId)
        Delegates to FragmentManager.findFragmentByTag(String) with the TAG obtained via FragmentFactory.createFragmentTag(int) from the current factory.

        Note, that this method assumes that there is factory attached and that factory provides fragment that is associated with the specified factoryFragmentId otherwise an exception is thrown.

        Parameters:
        factoryFragmentId - Id of the desired factory fragment to find.
        Returns:
        The requested fragment if found, null otherwise.
        Throws:
        IllegalStateException - If there is no factory attached.
        IllegalArgumentException - If the attached factory does not provide fragment for the specified id.

      • hasBackStackEntries

        public final boolean hasBackStackEntries()
        Checks whether there are some fragments within the back stack or not.
        Returns:
        True if fragments back stack contains at least one entry, false otherwise.
        See Also:
        FragmentManager.getBackStackEntryCount()

      • getTopBackStackEntry

        @Nullable
public final FragmentManager.BackStackEntry getTopBackStackEntry()
        Returns the top entry from the fragments back stack.
        Returns:
        The top back stack entry or null if there are no back stack entries.
        See Also:
        hasBackStackEntries()

      • clearBackStack

        public void clearBackStack()
        Clears fragments back stack by calling FragmentManager.popBackStack() in loop for current back stack size obtained via FragmentManager.getBackStackEntryCount().

        Note, that FragmentManager.popBackStack() is an asynchronous call, so the fragments back stack may be cleared in a feature, not immediately.

        See Also:
        clearBackStackImmediate()

      • clearBackStackImmediate

        public boolean clearBackStackImmediate()
        Like clearBackStack() but this will call FragmentManager.popBackStackImmediate() instead of FragmentManager.popBackStack().

        Note, that FragmentManager.popBackStackImmediate() is a synchronous call, so the fragments back stack will be popped immediately within this call. If there are too many fragments, this may take some time.

        Returns:
        True if there was at least one fragment popped, false otherwise.

      • destroy

        public final void destroy()
        Destroys this fragment controller instance, mainly un-registering its internal back-stack listener from the attached FragmentManager.

        Fragment controller should be destroyed whenever it is used in application component that has 'shorter' lifecycle (like fragment) as its parent application component (activity).

        Note, that already destroyed controller should not be used further as such usage will result in an exception to be thrown.
